gx.shapes Module¶

This module provides QPainterPath based classes with configurable shapes that can be easily connected to another existing path.

The blocks on Visuino are meant to be fully customizable, which means that values such as corner/notch sizes (width and lenght), shapes, etc, will be available to the end user through global configurations - i.e., changes will apply to all blocks on each category.

This module can also be executed on his own for testing all variations of attributes by using a simple GUI.

CornerPath class¶

class visuino.gx.shapes.CornerPath(start_point, rect_size, shape, place, clockwise=True)[source]¶

Bases: visuino.gx.utils.GxPainterPath

Path with the shape of a corner to be connected with other paths.

It has the following available shapes (self.SHAPES):

  • 'trig': inclinated line (diagonal of the bounding rectangle);
  • 'arc': circular - can be used to create rounded rectangles;
  • 'rect': regular rectangular corner;

For each one of those there is 4 possible places (see self.PLACES). Here we have an example of some 'top-right' corner of 'trig' shape:

-------------#\. . . .
             . \     .
             .  \    .
             .   \   .
             .    \  .
             .     \ .
             .      \ 
             . . . . @
                     |

Considering clockwise drawing, # would be the starting point and @, the ending (and vice-versa for counterclockwise drawing). PS: The dotted lines indicates the bounding rectangle for the corner.

The easiest way to go is using the connect() static method.

VALID_PLACES = ('bottom-left', 'bottom-right', 'top-left', 'top-right')¶
VALID_SHAPES = ('trig', 'arc', 'rect')¶
__init__(self, start_point, rect_size, shape, place, clockwise=True)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • start_point – QPointF Point from where this path will begin to draw.
  • rect_size – QSizeF Size of the bounding rectangle of the corner area. This is used to calculate the final point of the corner path.
  • shape – str in self.VALID_SHAPES Indicates the appearence of the corner path.
  • place – str in self.VALID_PLACES Indicates what kind of corner this will be on the final picture.
  • clockwise – bool Direction of the drawing.
connect(path, rect_size, shape, place, clockwise=True)[source]¶

This method provides a nice and clean way of connecting a corner path to another path. Here is some usage example:

>>> path = QPainterPath(QPointF(0, 0))
>>> path.lineTo(50, 0)
>>> CornerPath.connect(path, QSizeF(50, 50), 'trig', 'top-right')
>>> print(path.currenPosition())
QPointF(100.0, 50.0)
Parameters:
  • path – QPainterPath Path on which the corner will be connected. The current position will be used as the starting point for the corner path.
  • rect_size – QSizeF Size of the bounding rectangle of the corner area. This is used to calculate the final point of the corner path.
  • shape – str in self.VALID_SHAPES Indicates the appearence of the corner path.
  • place – str in self.VALID_PLACES Indicates what kind of corner this will be on the final picture.
  • clockwise – bool Direction of the drawing.

NotchPath class¶

class visuino.gx.shapes.NotchPath(start_point, rect_size, shape, direction, facing)[source]¶

Bases: visuino.gx.utils.GxPainterPath

Path with the shape of a notch to be used as “puzzle-like” connectors.

The available shapes are:

  • 'trig/%f': triangle or trapezium form;
  • 'arc/%f': circular corners;

The /%f part is optional on both cases, where %f must be a real number between 0.0 (default) and 1.0. It determines the lenght of the trapezium top side, relatively to the lenght of the trapezium base side. If 0.0, results on a triangular form for 'trig' shape, and on a perfect half-circle/ellipse form for 'arc' shape. If 1.0, then the lenght of the top is the same of the base, resulting on a rectangled notch for either shape value.

With the '+i' and '-i' directions (horizontal shapes), it can be facing 'up' or 'down'; similarly, with the '+j' and '-j' directions (vertical shapes), it can be facing 'left' or 'right'.

The following notch was constructed with '-j' direction and facing 'left':

                 |
                 @     +
                /      |
              /        |
            /          |
     +     |           |
     |     |           |
top  |     |           |  base
     +     |           |
            \          |
              \        |
                \      |
                 #     +
                 |

Here we have a 'trig/0.4' shape, where # is the starting point and @ the ending. The lenght of the top is 0.4 times the lenght of the base.

VALID_SHAPES = ('trig/%f', 'arc/%f')¶
VALID_DIRECTIONS = ('+i', '-i', '+j', '-j')¶
VALID_FACING_SIDES = ('up', 'down', 'left', 'right')¶
__init__(self, start_point, rect_size, shape, direction, facing)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • start_point – QPointF Point from where this path will begin to draw.
  • rect_size – QSizeF Size of the bounding rectangle for this path.
  • shape – str in self.VALID_SHAPES Shape of the notch.
  • direction – str in self.VALID_DIRECTIONS Indicates the direction of the drawing (using vectorial notation).
  • facing – str in self.VALID_FACING_SIDES Indicates to which side the top of the trapezium is going to be pointing on.
connect(path, rect_size, shape, direction, facing)[source]¶

This method provides a nice and clean way of connecting a notch path to another path. Here is some usage example:

>>> path = QPainterPath(QPointF(0, 0))
>>> path.lineTo(50, 0)
>>> NotchPath.connect(path, QSizeF(100, 50), 'trig/0.8', 'i+', 'down')
>>> print(path.currenPosition())
QPointF(150.0, 0.0)
Parameters:
  • path – QPainterPath Path on which the notch will be connected. The current position will be used as the starting point for the notch path.
  • rect_size – QSizeF Size of the bounding rectangle for this path.
  • shape – str in self.VALID_SHAPES Shape of the notch.
  • direction – str in self.VALID_DIRECTIONS Indicates the direction of the drawing (using vectorial notation).
  • facing – str in self.VALID_FACING_SIDES Indicates to which side the top of the trapezium is going to be pointing on.
